sols_html:
To get our bounds of integration, we need to know where the intersection points are. Also, from the graph, the top function changes, so we need to find out exactly where this occurs, which is another point of intersection. The intersections can be found by solving

\[\begin{aligned} 4+\pi \sin x &= 4+2\pi-2x \\ x &= \pi - \frac{\pi}{2} \sin x\end{aligned}\]

This isn’t easy to solve, but the graph shows three intersection points which can be estimated then checked. It looks like the three intersection points are \(\displaystyle x = \pi/2, \pi, 3\pi/2\). At \(\displaystyle x = \pi/2\),

\[\begin{aligned} \pi - \frac{\pi}{2} \sin \frac{\pi}{2} = \pi - \frac{\pi}{2} \cdot 1 = \frac{\pi}{2}\end{aligned}\]

so this is a solution. At \(\displaystyle x = \pi\),

\[\begin{aligned} \pi - \frac{\pi}{2} \sin \pi = \pi - \frac{\pi}{2} \cdot 0 = \pi\end{aligned}\]

so this is a solution. At \(\displaystyle x = 3\pi/2\),

\[\begin{aligned} \pi - \frac{\pi}{2} \sin \frac{3\pi}{2} = \pi - \frac{\pi}{2} \cdot (-1) = \frac{3\pi}{2}\end{aligned}\]

so this is a solution. Then, the intersection points are indeed \(\displaystyle x = \pi/2, \pi, 3\pi/2\). Notice the top function on \(\displaystyle [\pi/2,\pi]\) is \(\displaystyle 4+\pi \sin x\), whereas the top function on \(\displaystyle [\pi,3\pi/2]\) is \(\displaystyle 4+2\pi-2x\).

We have

\[\begin{aligned} A &= \int_{\pi/2}^{\pi} \left[(4+\pi \sin x) - (4+2\pi-2x)\right] \ dx \\ &\qquad + \int_{\pi}^{3\pi/2} \left[(4+2\pi-2x)-(4+\pi \sin x)\right] \ dx \\ &= (-\pi \cos x - 2\pi x + x^2)\big|_{\pi/2}^{\pi} + (\pi\cos x+2\pi x-x^2)\big|_{\pi}^{3\pi/2} \\ &= 2(\pi - \pi^2/4)\end{aligned}\]
